The formula for this, is extremely easy and can be explained as follows:

If we estimate, for example a 1% risk per year (o.o1) because of risk of misunderstandings, technical malfunction or terrorist attack for every year (probably lower most years, however probably much higher some years, and we look back at about 70 years with proliferation of missile based nuclear weapons, we simply get the formula 0.99^70 for survival, which equals to about 0.5 meaning 50% chance of survival so far!

I survived the Cold War (and you were able to be born) precisely because of deterrence (Mutually Assured Destruction).  Self preservation is HUMAN NATURE and deterrence needs to be put in those immutable/fundamental terms. 
That said, nuclear weapons create and solve certain problems confronting nation-states.  Nukes require a good command and control system with security locks to prevent unauthorized use.  Nukes require a robust early warning system to ensure an enemy's failure to launch a successful first strike.  Nukes require an infrastructure to safely manufacture, maintain and dispose of the nuclear material itself. 
Aside from ensuring an equally equipped opponent doesn't use them, nukes ensure territorial integrity from outside invasion and frees nation states of the burden of keeping large standing armies.  A single ICBM can do the work of an entire fleet of conventional bombers.

Some problems with the physicist's analysis.
1. The modernization projects launched by the US and Russia are upgrading delivery platforms, ie the missiles, submarines, and bomber aircraft. Both the US and Russia have halted production of new warheads and are instead using existing stockpiles. The upgrades both countries are pursuing aren't increasing the power of warheads, but instead focus on the deliverability of their payload. This actually allows for fewer warheads because there is less need to saturate a target with multiple nukes to guarantee their destruction. If anything, the Future of Life Institute should be supporting the new weapon systems to justify more aggressive campaigning for arsenal reduction.
2. The justification about deterrence needs being met by countries with small arsenals like Pakistan, North Korea, and India is that all of those nations are primarily regional powers with regional interests. It is also fairly ironic that the video uses North Korea and Pakistan as examples of sensible nuclear policy, since each of those nations are the considered to be the highest risk vectors for nuclear terrorism and proliferation. Countries like Britain and France have limited arsenals in no small part due to their participation in NATO, and can rely on coverage from the US. The same is likely true for China, which can still reasonably rely on Russia against Western nuclear aggression. If the arsenal was reduced to, say double digits, NATO member states will likely pursue their own weapons programs to get their deterrence needs met, again defeating the the purpose of counter proliferation.

This video has two huge mistakes, the radiation from a nuclear bomb just isn't as dangerous as implied, it certainly is not anywhere close to being as dangerous as the 'thermal' part of the explosion.

Reports on the WHO website confirm that the radiation from Hiroshima and Nagasaki (excluding the effect of smoke inhalation and other hazards which would be present) is about 1/3 as dangerous as if they all smoked 20 cigarettes a day.

The nuclear war could be started by accident is simply an urban myth. A far more likely cause of a nuclear war is one country's military deciding it is in their strategic interest to start one. Just like any other armed conflict.

Minute physics is normally excellent, so I can forgive this one slip up, but you really should take more effort to double check facts especially with emotive subjects such as this one.

This is the point I make to people when they talk about Fermi's Paradox. It's not that when a society gets to the point where they have nukes that they must be aggressive enough to kill each other with them, it's that the very presence of nukes creates a constant and ongoing random chance that the civilization will accidentally destroy itself, which simply never goes away, no matter what level of world peace they're experiencing.

Nukes are a Great Filter.

Only civilizations that can a) become advanced enough to create them, and b) successfully do away with them before they accidentally reset themselves back to the stone age are able to pass through it.

Given that, it stands to reason that if there are any civilizations out there ahead of us (and if you agree with the theory that all intelligent life in the universe has only had a several million year window to show up), then they've likely had to reset at least once, meaning there's a very good chance they're actually behind us technologically.

First, to be clear, nukes are not nice at all and I'm not making a case for hugging them.   That said, the "nuclear winter" theory has been mostly debunked and never really did have a lot of academic support.  Though it did have tremendous political support during the height of the cold war for obvious reasons.  Examples of "science" being led by politics are everywhere.  Consider the conspicuous absence of horrible mutations around Chernobyl or the absence of mutations passed on to the next generations in Hiroshima and Nagasaki, both effects solidly predicted by "science" of the day, for example.  As it turns out, radiation is not such a huge driver of deleterious transgenerational mutation as originally thought, but that is not politically expedient so you don't hear much about it.  After all, Godzilla is proof that radiation causes horrible mutations, right?  Which  again, isn't to say that nuclear weapons are a good thing.  Especially with Iran on the verge of getting them and terrorists lining up to buy from them.

Your concept regarding finite deterrence is incorrect. A small number of nukes isn't sufficient to keep a country and it's interests safe, at least not on its own. The supposed firepower of nuclear weapons is considerably lowered when different scenarios are envisioned. The numbers look impressive, but in an attack, a large number of nuclear weapons and delivery methods will likely be destroyed unless they are concealed by submarine, strengthened missile silos, etc...

We sign arms treaties to hinder the exponential growth of such powerful weapons that can be triggered by accident on any side. Some more effective policies for nuclear deterrence are credible first strike or counter-force as insurance. The concept in the video of having a small amount to deter large threats is called finite deterrence, and has been shown to be ineffective.

The money for nuclear arms research does not go to making more bombs, but to increase the reliability and overall technology of them. Old nukes are inaccurate, and require maintenance. Such funds go to restoring them in places like submarines (ex. Trident program), where the quantity of nuclear arms isn't so much important as their ability to exist after an attack. Submarines and other more modern delivery systems are used to attack an enemy that has already fired, and being behind in this technology can be fatal to the security of a nation. If the only insurance policy is gone, the whole program fails.

Arms treaties are the most effective way to deal with this problem. Boycotting companies who support the research and development of more advanced bombs is not nearly as effective as preventing the development of nuclear weapons in countries that may be still CRAZY ENOUGH TO FIRE THEM and still not a part of nuclear non-proliferation (India, Pakistan, North Korea, Israel).

The one thing I didn't hear in this video (and is actually a very good argument for downsizing the nuclear arsenals) is maintenance requirements. The more nukes you have, the more you have to maintain -- indefinitely -- You can't ever stop maintenance as long as you have them, or deterioration could make them a threat to the people who live and work near them. The more nukes you have, the more maintenance is required. That costs money, it costs personnel, and the more maintenance that is required, the higher the risk of a maintenance failure because let's face it: maintenance is done by humans, and humans aren't perfect and never will be. So keeping more than the bare minimum strategic interests demand is ultimately pretty poor strategic planning.

I agree with all or Max's arguments against stockpiling nukes except for one; possibly the most important one.  His assertion that ~80 nukes is enough to act as a deterrent assumes that every nuke launched will reach its intended target.  If country X and Y both have 80 nukes, but X has defensive systems that are able to destroy 75 of 80 inbound nukes and Y does not, then Y's nukes are not a deterrent to X's aggression.  In order for Y's stockpile to be a deterrent, Y must have enough nukes to overwhelm X's defenses or have very clever nukes that can evade them (which would then kick off an arms race for defensive technologies ... which actually happened and is why Russia dislikes the US's European-based "missile shield" so much).

Recent scientific modeling of a nuclear winter scenario demonstrates that even a regional or "localized" nuclear strike, involving "only" 50 or so Hiroshima-sized weapons, on large metropolitan cities with a lot of combustible material, would be enough to induce nuclear winter and a global collapse of agriculture.

Alan Robock, climate scientist at Rutgers University, is one of the many scholars working on this. See his home page http://climate.envsci.rutgers.edu/nuclear/ for a huge collection of materials.

In a February 11, 2016 NY Times Op Ed, "Let's End the Peril of a Nuclear Winter" Robock writes: "A nuclear war between any two countries using 100 Hiroshima-size atom bombs, less than half of the combined arsenals of India and Pakistan, could produce climate change unseen in recorded human history."

This is not correct.  I do this sort of stuff for a living, and I worked at Cheyenne Mountain in Space Command from 1999 to 2001.  The (approximate) 14000 nukes, to cause an alleged, hypothetical nuclear winter would have to be global and spread-out detonations pretty evenly.  It's unlikely either nation would nuke the South Pacific and South Indian Oceans.  You have to consider the global atmosphere density and prevailing winds in each region, such as the Arctic Vortex, etc.  Different yields produce vastly different results, and most are designed to detonate above the ground-surface anyway, causing minimal dust needed for an alleged nuclear-winter.  Even if they were all detonated evenly-spaced, on the ground causing maximum dust, the hypothetical winter couldn't last more than approximately 1.5 years.  Do some math here next time guys.

Wow...having studied nuclear weapons extensively for over a year, I am pretty disappointed in this video. Minute Physics, I thought you were better at doing your homework.

First, the propaganda-esque word choices--"kill millions of people," "radioactive fallout, which would kill even more," etc. The explosions could potentially kill millions, if detonated in the heart of a large city, but the radiation wouldn't "kill even more". Damage caused by the total radiation from all nuclear tests is highly contestable, because it's calculated on a linear scale: meaning they assume if a lot will hurt you to death, a little will hurt you a little. This is not true, and accurate models actually show that some increase in exposure to radiation is beneficial, which is why sunbathing is good for you, or why flying (which exposes you to a great deal of radiation) doesn't kill you.

The biggest threat isn't a nuclear winter, as that scenario is so far from being likely it's absurd--that's like claiming the biggest threat to earth is a huge meteor hitting it, causing another ice age (the same thing as nuclear winter, but not from atomic weapons). The US hires hundreds of people to regularly replace and upkeep their nuclear arsenal, and the Russian arsenal is mostly disconnected and stored in various pieces. Additionally, to even launch a nuclear weapon, there are 3-10 safeguards in place that all have to be simultaneously activated, included key slots on opposite sides of a large room that both have to be turned within less than a second of each other, making it pretty impossible for them both to short or for one person to launch them both. No nuclear weapons are wired to automatically fire--all are configured to require multiple layers of human interaction, and then computer safeguards are stacked on top of that.

Close calls will never equal automatic nuclear weapon launch. Owning more nuclear weapons is not a security threat any more than a few are for the same reasons mentioned above--they will not automatically launch, and guarding <100 nukes is the same as guarding more--you just duplicate the security in multiple facilities. And America at least takes this obligation very seriously--like I said, they have hundreds of highly-educated technicians, physicists, and engineers who team with security and other personnel to upkeep and maintain the things--including keeping them from falling into the wrong hands. I've applied for this job, and read through the requirements for it--it's pretty intense.

The cause you're pushing is not a bad one, but the way you introduced it is worse than terrible. What you may not realize is the many, many benefits of the nuclear industry are colored as bad by poorly researched/presented information like this. Hundreds of thousands of people would die every year without the bounteous boon of nuclear technologies, but folks only hear propaganda like this and think that everything nuclear is bad. Were you aware that the Department of Homeland Security pushed to get regulatory control over isotopes because the Nuclear Regulatory Commission was "letting them out to the public"? Allowing silly things like medical isotopes and measurement isotopes loose in the world? And that they were planning to ban all isotopes, because "isotopes are nuclear--isn't that bad"?

The total lack of understanding surrounding nuclear in general isn't helped by videos like this, which serve to present highly emotionally charged content devoid of much fact to make the public fear nuclear...enough of my rant. I'm very disappointed, MinutePhysics. I hope you make a video about the benefits of nuclear technologies or at least offer some correction to the misinformation here.

I assume "upgrade their arsenals at a huge cost" also includes some improvements to safety and modernization. If we are going to have them, I would prefer that they be as safe and accurate as possible. The idea of bombs or missiles built decades ago being active and just sitting around waiting for someone to push the big red button seems like a far more disturbing safety issue than the remote possibility of the US or Russia "accidentally" launching 1,000 nukes at once.

It's also a little disturbing that none of them have even been tested in over 20 years (with the exception of North Korea). The test ban treaty certainly didn't stop countries from building and designing new weapons, it just prevents them from being able to test those weapons to ensure their functionality and safety procedures. Let that sink in ... no nuclear weapon build in the last 20 years has ever been fully tested. You're never going to get rid of nuclear weapons unless something better comes along. It makes more sense (and seems safer) to have standardized testing methods and a limited number of annual tests available than to have untested or outdated arsenals in active use.

There is no evidence for nuclear winter at all.  We had similarly large, widespread fires during the firebombing during WW2, and we did not see a decades-long winter.  Further, modern structures are less flammable than the wooden and paper houses of WW2-era Japan, so we would have LESS fires.  Last, cities would not be primary, or even secondary targets in a nuclear exchange.  The main targets are your opponent's command and control, and their missile silos.

I'm sceptical of the number of nukes required to kick off a nuclear winter. The numbers used for predicting nuclear winter are from a long time ago. Buildings are now more commonly made of concrete, steel, brick and mortar, and less commonly out of wood, and other such flammable materials. This is particularly true of big cities (one potential group of targets). The other targets for nuclear strikes are airbases, navy ports, and the nuclear silo sites of the enemy, here there is not so much material to burn.
While the initial radiation of the first instant of a nuclear explosion is incredibly high, and will begin to incinerate things almost instantaneously, this heat does not last long, and is followed by a tremendous blast wave which can put out fires by starving them of air.
Not saying that a nuclear winter cannot happen, just this idea that there are enough nuclear weapons to destroy the world several times over is nothing more than a myth.
Some other myths, in the event of nuclear war, everyone dies. Not everyone will die. Almost certainly the majority of people will survive. Many will be severely injured, and many rural folk wont have any idea of what is happening. People will more likely die from existing in a lawless world where many of the institutions and industry we take for granted no longer functions.
Secondly, radioactive fallout is not a primary consideration, the air will be safe to breath pretty swiftly because all the major nuclear powers use air burst strikes for maximum destructive power. Fallout occurs in ground burst and near ground burst strikes. And the only people to employ that tactic are forces without high tech missiles, such as North Korea, Iran, and terrorist organisations. These kind of nuclear strikes will be localised, and not global.

By the time the president of a country is notified that radar has detected a SLBM (submarine launched ballistic missile), he has less than ten minutes to decide whether to launch a retaliatory strike before the EMP pulse will take out his ability to communicate or to detect additional incoming missiles.  When the Norwegian rocket was mistaken as a SLBM, Yeltsin gave orders to all his nuclear forces to be on standby to launch a retaliatory strike, and it was the only time the nuclear brief case of either country was ever activated.  If it had been someone other than Yeltsin in charge, the incident may have ended in a full scale nuclear war.

If the time ever comes and we will need to nuke [insert enemy here] you're going to wish we had more than a handful of nukes. In all likelihood the enemy will have a way of shooting down some percentage of incoming missiles, and if we only have ten or twenty nukes, they won't be hard to pick off when we send them downrange.
So we need many many more nuclear weapons per target, because several of them will be intercepted on their way over.
Not to forget, in a protracted scenario (e.g.: A full-scale nuclear war with the Soviets that probably would have lasted more than 60 minutes) would require a healthy reserve of nuclear weapons to mount subsequent waves of attacks.
